body: A CHARTER bus from Holyoke, Mass., was parked outside Lou Newkirk's antiques shop in the Port Morris section of the Bronx on a recent raw Saturday afternoon. Inside, Anne Tracy and her daughter, Becky, from Berkshire, Mass., were browsing. The bus driver, Gary Despres, had deposited other in-town-for-the-day shoppers from Massachusetts in midtown
title: A Bronx Antiques Row Brings Hope for Renewal

body: Asked just a year ago whether they would have supported legislation to severely curtail the power of community school boards, many parents and teachers in District 15 in Brooklyn would have answered loudly in the negative. The district, which straddles working-class neighborhoods in South Brooklyn and more affluent brownstone blocks in Park Slope,
title: In South Brooklyn, Guarded Desire for Change

body: Francis Patrelle, a veteran choreographer, remembers exactly where he was when he began conceiving his new version of ''The Nutcracker'': lost on his way home to Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. ''I was trying to get to the F.D.R. Drive,'' he said, ''and suddenly I saw it, all lit up: Gracie Mansion. I never knew it was there on 88th Street.'' Thus was
title: If Clara Had Met Her Nutcracker Prince on East End Ave.

body: Three thousand signatures later, Charles J. Hamm is keeping his word. Last May, Mr. Hamm, the president of Brooklyn-based Independence Savings Bank, promised Red Hook residents, who must travel to Carroll Gardens or other neighborhoods to do their banking, that he would open a branch in the neighborhood if a local advocacy group collected 3,000
title: Banker Delivers on His Pledge

body: During a typical evening rush hour at Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues, the traffic police wrestle with cars backed up for six blocks. All around them, the area is teeming with office workers heading home, parents buying groceries and teen-agers cruising. It is evidence that Downtown Brooklyn is outgrowing itself. Chronic traffic congestion has
title: For Downtown Traffic, Growing Pains May Turn Critical

body: For years, residents of western Brooklyn have dreaded the upcoming reconstruction of the Gowanus Expressway, a project that would swamp neighborhoods with traffic for at least five years. But an alternative may be emerging: replacing the crumbling elevated expressway with an underground highway. Ultimately, the most important question is whether
title: As Unpopular Gowanus Overhaul Looms, a Tunnel Plan Gains Notice

body: Eileen C. Dugan, a Brooklyn Democrat who was elected to her ninth term in the New York State Assembly only on Tuesday, died yesterday at Beth Israel Medical Center. Ms. Dugan, who lived in Carroll Gardens, was 51. The cause was breast cancer, according to her family. Gov. George E. Pataki, who served in the Assembly with Ms. Dugan, ordered state
title: Eileen C. Dugan, 51, State Assemblywoman

body: The bus carrying the triumphant Yankees arrived at Yankee Stadium shortly after midnight, greeted by more than 4,000 fans celebrating their arrival and camping out to buy World Series tickets. An exuberant Wade Boggs jumped off the bus, dropped his bags and ran to the crowd dispensing high-fives. The city's celebration began hours before, on the
title: Pennant Elates Yankee Fans in an Almost Spiritual Fashion

body: Creeping through midtown traffic recently in his dark blue Ford Explorer, the city's new Transportation Commissioner, Christopher R. Lynn, was rattling off his accomplishments to a passenger when he suddenly told his driver to stop and called the agency's central dispatcher. ''I want this fixed by the end of the day,'' barked Mr. Lynn, staring up
title: Quick Fixes In the Bureau Of Potholes

body: THREE years ago, Alan Marks, a Park Slope real-estate agent, would watch a one-bedroom apartment on Sackett Street, in an area known as the Lower Slope, languish on his list of rentals for longer than a month. Prospective tenants would take one look at the block, dotted with abandoned buildings and a few scraggly trees, turn up their noses and keep
title: The Boom in Park Slope

body: UPPER EAST SIDE The Rescuing of Many Jews By the Righteous in Italy ''The Righteous Enemy'' is a documentary film that tells the story of how members of the Italian Army and diplomatic corps saved the life of a Jew during the Holocaust. title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: The Gold Star Pizzeria at Avenue O and West Third Street in Brooklyn sits on a corner virtually indistinguishable from those of dozens of family-owned cafes that dot the mostly middle-class landscape of Bensonhurst. Its neighborhood is one of well-kept apartment buildings and two-family houses with yards and porches surrounded by plaster flower
title: In a Well-Kept Part of Brooklyn, Crack Arrests Are Met With Concern

body: Sure, sure. We know. There's just not enough time in the day, the month, the whole year, for that matter. You would love to exercise, plow through books, play an instrument, learn a foreign language. You'd even floss your teeth if you had more time. But hey, there is only one of you. You have a demanding job, a busy schedule and you've got to sleep
title: Not Enough Time in a Day? Meet the Master Jugglers

body: Voters who turned up for a bitterly contested primary in Brooklyn yesterday were turned away from scores of polling places, because election workers had failed to deliver the voting machines in time. The problem persisted into the afternoon in many neighborhoods, raising the prospect that the election would have to be held again. Officials said
title: Primary Voting in Brooklyn Disrupted by Lack of Machines

body: WHEN you grow tired of stylish gardens and stylish garden magazines, when you find yourself wanting to set fire to a Smith & Hawken garden bench, then go down to the sea, to Red Hook, Brooklyn. There, wild Virginia creeper climbs over the ruins of abandoned buildings, and a meadow of Queen Anne's lace runs down to a sandy beach. A band of gardeners
title: Blossoms From Rust in Red Hook

body: The pitch is simple: Want a bank in the neighborhood? Sign below. Wally Bazemore has taken this offer to the park benches of the Red Hook Houses and filled petitions with dozens of his neighbors' signatures. title: In an Isolated Corner, 3,000 Sigatures Equals a Bank

body: There certainly is no shortage of gripes about road construction projects in the city. The Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive seems perpetually snarled. title: Road Reconstruction Project Takes Path of Least Resistance

body: APPLAUSE, please, where it's due. Subway lines on Manhattan's West Side took a bath, literally, when a geezer of a water main became a geyser over the weekend, yet the Transit Authority resumed normal runs within 16 hours. Not bad. But that fine performance does not diminish rider dissatisfaction with overall service. If reader mail to this corner
title: NYC;On Subways, On Sidewalks, A Few Pleas

body: A young man looked up from his newspaper Friday morning, briefly noted the cityscape trundling by outside the F train, and returned to his paper. He looked up again a couple of minutes later, wrinkled his brow, sighed, and said, to no one in particular, "We're still not at Church Avenue? I hate this train." Those words from Danny Slotkin, a
title: Passengers Are Frustrated by Slower Commutes on Subways

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS;Housing May Replace Barren Lot

body: Friday nights at the Brooklyn Moon Cafe are vaguely reminiscent of an earlier era: Fingers snap, fists are raised in tribute to the spoken word, a few in the crowd sport sunglasses. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORT GREENE;Of Latte and the Literati: A Renaissance of Readings

body: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and fire officials first proposed shutting down New York City's fire alarm boxes more than a year ago, they said it would reduce false alarms and save $5 million a year. New Yorkers, they added, would be better served by the city's modern, expansive telephone system than by its antiquated network of 16,300 alarm
title: Phone Scarcity Complicates Fire Alarm Plan

body: Prompted by a rash of illegal betting on the Super Bowl, about 100 law enforcement officers and members of the Brooklyn District Attorney's office raided 14 gambling operations Saturday in Brooklyn and Queens and on Staten Island. The police arrested 26 people and confiscated about $25,000 in cash, as well as telephones, satellite television
title: Police Arrest 26 in Raids On 14 Gambling Operations

body: IT was a few days after the violent robbery that had killed Abdul Kareem Alsahybi in his Brooklyn delicatessen. The store was closed, bags filled with bullet-riddled cigarette packs and other evidence clogged the aisle, and Mr. Alsahybi's blood still stained the floor. But the lottery machine, destroyed in the shootout on Friday night, had already
title: Metro Matters;Death in Deli And Worries Over Lottery

body: Mary Sansone has often said that if her basement walls could talk, she and her husband would be in jail. "Well, maybe not in jail," Mrs. Sansone amended, making it clear that she has always worked against gangsters, not for them. "But we'd end up dead." title: A Godmother Of Politics For Giuliani
